derivation.yuyuan_name: Old English sēar (adjective), sēarian (verb), of Germanic origin

entry.def: To sear something means to burn its surface with a sudden intense heat.

example.ex: Grass fires have seared the land near the farming village of Basekhai.
example.tran: 草地野火烧焦了巴斯克亥农庄附近的土地。

entry.def: If something sears a part of your body, it causes a painful burning feeling there.

example.ex: I distinctly felt the heat start to sear my throat.
example.tran: 我分明感觉到嗓子开始烧得难受。

sentences.sentence: "my eyebrows singed when I bent over the flames"

means.word_mean: 3. cause to wither or parch from exposure to heat;
1. (used especially of vegetation) having lost all moisture;

sentences.sentence: "the desert was edged with sere vegetation"
